pr_title: Improve error handling on GROBID server connection issues

timeline.message:
add explicit configuration for connectTimeout in URLDownload
add information on GROBID server connection issue for user
relates to #6517 and #6891
fix style issues detected by checkstyle

timeline.bodyText: I think it's not so important for the user which exact url failed (especially since the popup disappears to quickly to type it in the url of a webbrower to check). So I suggest the following wording: "Could not connect to JabRef server (Connection timed out)."
timeline.author: tobiasdiez

replies.bodyText: And maybe add the details via error log.
replies.author: tobiasdiez

replies.bodyText:
Fair point, @tobiasdiez.
This should be "Could not connect to GROBID server (Connection timed out)." Shouldn't it?
replies.author: nitram509

replies.bodyText: I would still say "JabRef server"...the user knows what Jabref is, but not necessarily what grobid is. I would see this also as an "implementation detail", maybe in the future we switch the backend from grobid to something else..
replies.author: tobiasdiez

replies.bodyText:
It was tricky to get the Message to a phrase as you proposed.
I reduced the level of detail towards:
"There are connection issues with a JabRef server. Detailed information: %0."
(See latest screenshot)

Is this OK for you @tobiasdiez ?
replies.author: nitram509

timeline.bodyText: Please use ParserException instead of the uncheckedioex.
timeline.author: tobiasdiez

replies.bodyText:
Hmm 🤔
But that's not a ParserException, we are not even at the point of parsing yet.
Also, ParserException is a checked one, which has way more side-effects in terms of refactoring than an unchecked one.
Since you're one of the maintainers ... may I ask for your advise?
Here's the situation: the fetcher implementation before my PR did catch all exceptions (especially all IO related ones).
When an IOException is bubbling up in the call hierarchy, then it will get captured, as said.
The SearchBasedFetcher.performSearch method declaration does not mention any exception.
So when I want to throw e.g. a ParserException (I would prefer IOException because of its technical nature, though)
then I need to adapt the interface/abstract class and this will lead to many more files changed.
Would this be in your interest and aligned with your general architecture, @tobiasdiez ?
replies.author: nitram509

replies.bodyText:
Good catch, not sure where I was with my thoughts... I meant of course the FetcherException instead of ParserException. The general idea is to use FetcherException for everything that is semi-forseeable (e.g. connection time outs, bad response errors etc). So that would be the case here as well.
You are right that it might lead to a bit more refactoring as it's a checked exception, but I see this as an advantage instead of an disadvantage. Makes the code more robust and ensures that we covered all the cases where the user might want to prefer to see a user-friendly exception message instead of only having a cryptic one or only a debug log message.
Note also that you should provide the cause of the FetcherException already when it's created (since that's usual the point where you can figure out what went wrong).
replies.author: tobiasdiez

replies.bodyText:
I did follow the idea and used the FetcherExeption. That was simple.
There's one caveat though, because of Java Stream don't play well with checked exceptions, I had to wrap IOException in RuntimeException. Since this is wrapped and un-wrapped within the same class, I hope you agree, in this is acceptable.
The exception thrown by the fetcher is a FetcherException, as discussed.
replies.author: nitram509

timeline.author: tobiasdiez

replies.bodyText: Good catch. Quite convenient and overseen, thank you.
replies.author: nitram509

timeline.bodyText: Very good that you added a test as well. Small suggestion for improvement: use Assertions.assertThrows to ensure that the exception is indeed thrown.
timeline.author: tobiasdiez

replies.bodyText: Will have a look. Thank you.
replies.author: nitram509
